title: Answer Logo? (Font ID)
content:
Anyone know the name of this typeface?

[http://www.answerking.net/index\_files/image001.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642/http:/www.answerking.net/index_files/image001.gif "http://www.answerking.net/index\_files/image001.gif")
author: Michael Jarboe

comments.content:
Reminds me of Harold's Fonts Popups. But more square.

Similar [Powerstation](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642/http:/www.fontbros.com/cgi-bin/commerce.cgi?preadd=action&key=ALSO-PSBL)

I just fontstructed something in this style. A lot more naive (due to the limitations of the program) but free for non-commercial use:

[Chromatose](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642/http:/fontstruct.fontshop.com/fontstructions/show/chromatose) and its  
 [Solid variant](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642/http:/fontstruct.fontshop.com/fontstructions/show/chromatose_solid).

- Lex

Another similar one is [Fire Down Below](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/fire-down-below-nf/) from Nick's Fonts.

I've just tried out the previously suggested Popups.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140420083642im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ANSWER_6140.gif)

It doesn't look quite as sharp but is otherwise a very good match. Perhaps they used Popups but re-drew it to look sharper?

Although looking at both, neither seem to have got the prismatic effect to work on the W properly!
